The Shadow Brexit Secretary revealed his leadership bid speaking exclusively to the Sunday Mirror and admits Labour face an “uphill struggle” against Boris Johnson ’s Commons majority.But he says the party must hold the Tory government to account for the promises they made before the election. The Shadow Brexit Secretary will  launch his campaign during a visit to Brexit-backing Stevenage. Shadow Business Secretary Rebecca Long Bailey, a Jeremy Corbyn ally favoured on the left of the party, is still “seriously considering” whether to run for the leadership - as is party chairman Ian Lavery, who is also close to Mr Corbyn.But London MP David Lammy ruled himself out of the race on Saturday. He said: “I’m committed to playing my full part in opposition, but we need the candidate best placed to unite our party’s factions so we can win the country’s trust.” Ms Phillips visited the Bury North constituency that fell from Labour to the Tories to meet former supporters who did not back the party in the last election.

title: labours lisa nandy horrific benefits
story: NewsLabours Lisa Nandy on the horric benefits case that helped find her political voiceEXCLUSIVE The Labour leadership hopeful was appalled when she spoke to a rape victim, and learned what she had to do to get helpShareCommentsByGrace Macaskill :,  JAN Updated:,  JAN News" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSitting next to a startled rape victim, Lisa Nandy looked in to her eyes and made a solemn promise to make her le better. Left emotionally and physically scarred, the young woman faced having her benefits stopped unless she agreed to a physical medical exam which proved she was unable to work. Enraged, Nandy says it fuelled the seminal moment when, as a new MP in , she first found her voice. The Labour Leader contender, , said: “This young lady had been traumatised by the horric rape she had suffered. The way she’d been treated by the benefits system had compounded that. “When she told me she had to undergo a medical exam I just thought ‘over my dead body’. “There’s something about Parliament that can be very intimidating when you first arrive. You need to find your confidence really quickly, otherwise you can’t make change and it was her terrible story which made me find my voice.  “I told Teresa May thatshe got one more letter asking her for an exam I would raise hell and the issue was sorted. She was given two years without being sent any more letters and got the head space she needed to recover. “I didn’t feel apologetic about taking up time or forcing things onto the agenda. In many ways this young woman made me feel I didn’t have a right not to. That was a game changer for me.” Nandy has thrown her hat into the ring as Jeremy Corbyn ’s replacement. Today it’s hard to imagine that the chatty, humorous mother-of-one ever struggled with voicing her views Boris Johnson is not to be trusted, regional devolution of powers is a good thing, the north’s transport system needs improving. Above all , Labour needs a new focus after it’s “devastating” defeat to the Tories and, living in its Northern heartlands, she is the woman “with skin in the game”. She says she will not move to Londonshe wins the race . “If the Labour leader cannot live in Wigan and travel for work in London, then there’s something wrong with Labour and the country.” Like many female MPs, Nandy has been subject to misogynistic and political abuse but also about her Indian heritage. Her father Dipak is a Marxist academic who helped draw up the race relations act – meaning she has also been subjected to racism. She refuses to be cowed by threats saying: “I won’t let them stop me. “What is the alternative for this countrypeople, particularly women , can be hounded out of public le through violence, abuse and fear ” She lives with her partner, PR man Andy Collis, and their four-year-old son. When Nandy took a soft Brexit approach to Europe, advocating we leave the European Union but keep close ties with our neighbours, she spent three years being pummelled by abuse. She said: “I was getting it from every side. Those who voted remain told me I was a traitor for wanting Brexit, while those on the other side said I had thrown democracy down the river.”  Nandy, who carries a panic alarm and has panic buttons in her home like many women MPs, said: “The abuse over the last three years has been astronomical some of it misogynistic, some of it deeply sexist, some downright abusive and some threatening. “When I was first selected I had notes through my door and letters to the office, saying ‘you need to get out of this country’ and ‘you need to leave politics’. “Right-wingers were at the centre of it and they tried to slash my car tyres but got my neighbours instead. “Some people wrote on message boards that I was a secret Muslim and planned to tear down the Anvil pub in Wigan and put up a statue of a woman in a burqa. “It gathered some traction because people were emailing askingI was Muslim. I’d write back saying ‘I’m an atheist but I have respect for every religion.’ I think they eventually came a cropper when other people started posting on these messages that I often spent my Fridays nights in the Anvil! She admits being shaken when fellow MP Jo Cox was murdered. “I sat down with my partner and we had a conversation in which we said ‘is it worth it ’, she says. “He feels very strongly that it is because, in the end, do you want to bring your kids up in a world where we allow these people to win ”  She seems mystied as to how anti-semitism sentiment in her own party got out of control. If elected Leader, she will move quickly to stamp it out. She was shadow cabinet for Energy and Climate Change in  when Bradford MP Naz Shah was caught up in a row over anti-Jewish social media posts. Jeremy Corbyn caused tensions by refusing to suspend her straight away.  Nandy said: “I went from pillar to post over a course of  hours trying to get the Party to take it seriously and couldn’t get anywhere with it, despite some people on the inside trying to help me.” AskedCorbyn is to blame for Labour Party issues Nandy refuses to directly criticise the hand that fed her on her rise to possible leadership. She has known Corybn since she was a -year-old researcher for MP Neil Gerrard. She says: “I don’t think the Labour Party is anti-Semitic because most members hate racism as much as poverty. Don’t forget it’s working class people, often Labour Party members, who have driven the far right out of town over and over again over decades. They hate racism and they feel badly let down.” Nandy left her Shadow Cabinet position in  when it became clear to her Labour in-fighting was going to rage on between the Corybnites and their rivals. She says: “I got a very strong steer the factional war was never going to end and they were going to fight it out until one side had won and the other had lost.” While her father, , is a leading academic light, Nandy credits her mum Luise, , for being the most inspirational person in her le. The couple split when Nandy was seven, but the MP hates the term single parent household “because I had two parents, they just happened to live in dferent houses.” One of her earliest memories involves politics when she went out canvassing and delivering leaflets with her mum, who stood as a local councillor.

story: NewsCosta del Sol swimming pool deaths: Brit familys bodies due to be repatriatedThe deaths of the London family in a Club La Costa World pool in Spain has left we and mum of the victims Olubunmi Diya with questions about what happened to her loved onesShareCommentsByGerard Couzens:,  JAN NewsGabriel Diya with his daughter Favour , son Praise-Emmanuel who died, and their mum Olubnmi " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe bodies of the British dad and his two children who drowned in a Costa del Sol swimming pool were due to be repatriated today. Officials took the bodies to Malaga Airport in three funeral hearses on Saturday morning so they could be flown back to the UK  days after the Christmas Eve holiday tragedy that claimed their lives. Gabriel Diya, , and his children Comfort, nine, and Emmanuel-Prince, , lost their lives after taking their first holiday dip at their pool on the Club La Costa World resort near Fuengirola, Spain. Police have described the incident as a “tragic accident” caused by the victims’ lack of swimming skills. But Christian preacher Mr Diya’s widow Olubunmi, who ed to the UK with her surviving daughter Favour, , last Saturday, has hired a Spanish lawyer after claiming her loved ones could all swim and there was something wrong with the pool. An investigation led by a court in Fuengirola is ongoing. Police tests have shown up no anomalies with the pool. Mrs Diya’s lawyer Javier Toro has said he could press for new tests on the pool done by engineers he would hire for the job once he has read through the police report.  It was not clear today when the funerals of Mr Diya and his children would take place. The plane carrying their bodies was expected to reach the UK late afternoon. Mr Diya, who lived with his family in Charlton, south east London, was a pastor at a branch in the capital of the Redeemed Christian Church of God . Pastor Agu Irukwu, chairman of the RCCG board of trustees in the UK, told thenewspaper overnight he had spent time with Mrs Diya and she had been grieving but showing “grace and dignity. He said: “My we and I were really amazed at the grace and dignity she is exhibiting at a time like this. “We left there thinking we had been in the presence of a remarkable woman.”  Heartbroken Favour Diya told police after the tragedy she had come close to suffering the same fate as her siblings after “sliding towards the deep part” of the pool which was in the middle. She admitted to never having swum in areas where she was out of her depth but told cops who interviewed her when she was askedshe could remember any suction or current in the pool: “The water was moving but I don’t know how to explain it.” Although Favour told police she was not aware the deepest part of the pool was in the middle, the children’s mum insisted to investigators she had told her youngest girl Comfort.  In a statement released three days after the tragedy through her lawyer, Mrs Diya said: “I would like to thank all those who have sent their condolences and supported our family during this extremely dficult time following the tragic deaths of Gabriel, Comfort and Praise-Emmanuel. “Our family are utterly heartbroken by the events last Tuesday but we are comforted and strengthened by our strong faith in our Lord Jesus Christ. “We are deeply shocked, saddened and struggling to come to terms with their passing.

title: couple remarry 17 years after
story: NewsCouple remarry  years after their first marriage ended in painful orceJan and Rob Shakespeare tied the knot for the second time,  years after their first wedding, after tragedy brought the pair back togetherShareCommentsByHelen Whitehouse:,  JAN NewsJan and Rob Shakespeare tying the knot for the second time " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Because the couple’s first wedding took place in  and ended in a painful orce back in . And for nearly  years the pair, who had three children together, never spoke. They even stood at opposite sides of the football pitch whenever they watched youngest son Adam play. They also managed to get through two of their boys’ weddings without saying a word to each other. But it was tragedy that brought them back together, with Jan consoling Rob over the loss of his second we.  It made the pair, now , realise le was too short for their rt to go on – and that the love sparked when they met at a Woolworths store as teenagers was still burning. Rob says: “Jan was my first love and we will be growing old together as I definitely can’t afford another wedding – or a orce.” And Jan, who had the ceremony she dreamed of second time around in , says: “We married in a registry office first time. This time I wore a big white dress and we got married in a church. “Our children,  grandchildren and one great-grandchild were with us. It was perfect and I’m back with my best friend.” The lovebirds first met in  in the days of flares and s at a Woollies store in Erdington, Birmingham. Jan worked in the office and Rob in the stockroom. Within a year they were dating. Jan recalls: “Rob and I were just . I was a cashier and he was pretty much my bodyguard, going round the tills with me collecting money twice a day. “He asked me out at a works Christmas dance. Our first date was watching a film we hadn’t realised was X-rated and there were quite a few men wearing flasher macs in the cinema. “We had to leave but we didn’t stop laughing.” The couple moved in together at . “I fell pregnant and our parents weren’t happy but it was planned,” Jan said. “We were excited about the future. “We got married soon after I turned  in September . “I had a white dress, but not a proper wedding one, and I was five- and-a-half months pregnant.”  Daughter Cara was born on Christmas Day and the couple went on to have Lee, now , and Adam, now . But  years into their marriage, cracks started to show. Jan was made redundant from her job in Boots and started working shts at another company. She and Rob barely saw each other. She says: “I absolutely loved working at Boots and I think I had a bit of a breakdown after being made redundant. “Rob was always saying he didn’t see enough of me in my new job. I was working until  at night. We started arguing about that a lot and I just got fed up. I left and we didn’t speak properly again for years.” The couple separated in  and Rob filed for a orce, which came through in . Both met new partners and Rob remarried two-and-a-half years after their split. Rob says: “I never thought I’d find love again, but I did. My second we was an absolutely wonderful woman.” Although Rob and Jan’s paths crossed occasionally, they didn’t speak for years.  Jan says: “Adam played football and we’d both go and watch him, standing at opposite sides of the pitch. It was strange. We even made it through two of our sons’ weddings without talking. “Lee was married first. Rob and I were both with dferent people and just sat in dferent places. “When our son Adam had a wedding reception, again we didn’t talk to each other.“The only time we ever did wasafter we lost a grandchild. I was in hospital, crying.“Rob put his arm around me and said, ‘It’ll be OK, sweetheart’. I don’t know why we never talked.” That all changed in  when their daughter Cara told her mum that Rob’s we had died of oian cancer. The tragedy broke the ice.  “I gave him a call and offered my condolences and said I was there for himhe needed me,” says Jan. “A couple of weeks later, he gave me a call and we chatted for  minutes and arranged to see each other for a coffee. “I found it was like being back with my best friend. It was so bizarre – we picked up where we had left off  years earlier.” Rob says: “It was wonderful. We just started to get along like we always had done.” The couple decided to start seeing each other again – but kept it from their children until Jan ended the relationship she was in.

Word of the latest closures was spread by members of the public who posted photos of store closure signs in shop windows on social media. However, in many cases HMV has not made any public announcements. The outlets affected are in Leeds, Reading, Plymouth, the Bullring in Birmingham, Worcester, Bury St Edmunds, Grimsby and Nuneaton. Plymouth’s Drake Circus HMV is making way for a fresh retailer, leaving the centre on January  and re-opening in the former Maplin store in nearby Cornwall Street, also in the heart of the city centre.  One disappointed shopper wrote on Twitter : “My heart dropped when I saw the Closing sign, then realised they’re just moving, sad to see the store go by glad Plymouth will still have a HMV! #hmv” . story: NewsIdentical twin took own le after three suicide attempts in less than a yearMatthew Siddorn, of Wirral, attempted to kill himself multiple times but his mum claims she couldnt get health authorities to take his mental health issues seriouslyShareCommentsByOlivia Williams:,  JAN NewsThe last photo Vicky took of her son, Matthew Siddorn " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA heartbroken mum has described how she tried desperately to warn health authorities her son was a a danger to himself, but he still managed to take his own le. Matthew Siddorn died at  years old after at least three known previous suicide attempts. Vicky Siddorn, from Bebington, Wirral, lost her son Matthew in April . Matthew left behind an identical twin brother, Daniel. The -year-old mum said Matthew was a happy, content and mischievous baby who did everything with his twin. Speaking to the Liverpool ECHO, Vicky said: Matthew was born exactly  minutes after his brother and Daniel never let him forget that. They were born four weeks early with no problems, he was just a lovely baby very content, slept right through at three weeks. Just a lovely baby, happy little boy, dead mischievous. The mum-of-three said her son excelled throughout school, but had a couple of wobbles when he was around -years-old. She added: After Matt died I have since found out that he had a couple of wobbles when he was about , but went to the doctor so he knew to ask for help. They asked himhe wanted to be referred to CAMHS but everything settled down. I am hearing voices and I am seeing a figure and itaposs telling me Iaposve got to hurt myself The former Wirral Grammar student earned a place to study Geology at Leicester University in September  - but just a few months into his first year, Vicky received a distressing phonecall while she was at work. The store healthcare assistant said she answered the phone to her son in February , telling the ECHO: I had been in work and Matthew had left a message - he was upset and distressed, so I phoned him back. He got really upset and he was crying and he said aposI need help mumapos, so I said aposokay tell meapos and he told me he had been hurting himself. He said aposI am hearing voices and I am seeing a figure and itaposs telling me Iaposve got to hurt myself or itaposs going to do stuff to my family or the people I love, Iaposm scared.apos  The -year-old told her son to come home and they visited their family GP who referred Matthew to mental health services. Vicky said due to her sonaposs conscientious nature he went back to university, but came straight back for his appointment at St Catherineaposs Hospital in Tranmere. Only  at the time, Matthew had started to self-harm, which Vicky said he was very open about with his family. He also kept a journal of his thoughts where he drew the shape he was seeing and described where he was hearing voices, which he took to the appointment. However, Vicky claims her son was only in the appointment for around  minutes. She said: I askedhe wanted me to go in with him and he said he was fine, he had his book with him. So I dropped him off and the distance in my car from my house to St Catherineaposs is less than  minutes. I literally dropped him off, he walked in and I went home and made myself a coffee. I was at home for a maximum of  minutes and I got a call from him saying he was done. The mum asked Matthew whether he had been diagnosed, given medication or a follow-up appointment. However, she claims Matthew was told he was tired and could go back to university despite showing his journal. Vicky said despite it being a little against their will Matthew went back to university and told his mumhe felt down or depressed he would visit the doctor there.  Matthewaposs first suicide attempt - a hysterical call from his twin brother and a race to hospital A week after ing to university in September , Vicky received a hysterical phone call from her son Daniel who told her his twin brother had tried to kill himself. She said: It was am and Daniel rang hysterically crying and he could not get the words out and said Matthew had tried to kill himself. One of Matthewaposs friends had tried to contact us, but weaposre ex-directory and they couldnapost get our home phone number so managed to get Danielaposs number. Vicky and her husband Steve drove straight to the hospital in Leicester, where Matthew had discharged himself due to being -years-old. She told her son he needed to come home and be under the care of family doctors and Wirral. The -year-old added: I kept blubbing and thinking the NHS will save him and thinking we will do this, we will get him help, look at me Iaposve had [depression] for nearly  years and Iaposm fine. He was just really despondent and hollow, its hard to describe until you look into their eyes. Obviously I had looked into Matthewaposs eyes for nearly  years and he always had a future, a plan, uni and loved his le and wanted to study in America. Mental health services in Wirral were contacted by the familyaposs GP, however at this point Vicky claims they were reassured the teenager didnapost have a mental health illness despite Matthew having auditory hallucinations and having made a suicide attempt, as well as self-harming. Matthew went back to Leicester where he had regular visits from doctors and counsellors, reassuring his mum he understood the gravity of his suicide attempt. Vicky said: I was a constant bag of nerves. I was having about three hours of sleep a night, I was permanently waiting for the phone to go, but I told myself Iaposve got to learn to calm down. Matthewaposs second suicide attempt - a message from his uni mates and a suicide letter left behind On Halloween , Vicky received a message from one of her sonaposs university friends saying Matthew had attempted suicide for the second time. Vicky said he pre-planned and researched his second attempt, leaving him in a secure unit in hospital. The mum-of-three also found a suicide letter. Vicky and her husband told Matthew he needed to quit university andhome to the Wirral for good. She said: We decided he had to come home and I need to be able to monitor him and go to meetings with him and he knew he needed too as well, he said aposyes I know I need to get better.apos Upon theirhome, Vicky said she phoned their GP again and made an emergency appointment with mental health services right away. The mum claims her son had an hour long appointment at Clatterbridge Hospital.  She added: I remember it being an hour as because I took a really heavy book thinking Iaposd be there for ages and looking at my watch. He came out and he was given no medication, they said he had no mental health illness and there didnapost really seem to be anything much. They said right you need to make these plans, things to look forward to. As December  rolled around, Vicky claims her son was insistent on helping his dad out at his grandmotheraposs house, only later to find out Matthew had hidden items there. The -year-old said Matthew walked the dog with her to work and they had arrangements where she would call her son to check in. She said: We had these little arrangements and I was only up the road and he seemed to be starting to look like he wanted to make plans for the future. We were still very cautious of him though and we thought mental health services were aware of him and he was seeing people. I know people are going to say - why didnapost you put him private care and I beat myself up everyday that we didnapost re-mortgage our house and that I didnapost force my way into the room into one of those meetings. Matthewaposs third suicide attempt - a worrying Facebook post and a call to police In December  Matthew  posted a cryptic message on Facebook, which a friend in Leicester spotted and managed to ring Merseyside Police before it was deleted. Matthew had made his third suicide attempt. His mum said: I was in work and my neighbours came up and said aposwe donapost want you to get too distressedapos and the minute they said that my stomach just dropped. Police had broken the door down and my boss drove me to our house. Itaposs like I revert to being a small child and perhaps a lot parents who lose children do this, you revert to wanting to be  years old again and want to run away to the park because youaposre so scared. Matthew wasnapost in his family home, but Vicky noticed the keys to her mother-in-laws house were missing. A nearby traffic officer drove to the house where he noticed blood. Matthew was found next to the fire in his grandmotheraposs house, sat on the sofa and waiting to die. Vicky said: I remember thinking now I really am scared and I donapost think anyone can save him now and then I started losing a little faith. I donapost think they understood the urgency - it was his third attempt. The -year-old claims her son was left in AE with no security in place and was left with a kne and fork. Vicky said: They had left him with the curtains that go round the bed and thick bedsheets at the end of the bed and I was sitting opposite him and I saw him look at those sheets and look at the curtain rail for a long time.  I thought I know what he is going to dohe is allowed to, he is going to do something. We had quite big discussions about it, which is pretty dark - having a conversation about your child trying to kill themself. Itaposs not a conversation you should have but then it should be at the same time. He was always very honest and open. The zone you go into he described it as a tunnel when the pain got too much and itaposs like a fog which takes over and you just do it. If it clears a little it and the pain lessens a little bit and people start talking to you, you push it away. He told me because I wanted to know, he said it was like having loads of Matthews and him - the Matthew who wants to get well canapost get out. Where is this place you think we can keep him safe  Vicky claims that a member of the mental health team arrived and said they would assess him in the morning. His shoes had been removed and the family were told security would bring him backhe tried to leave the hospital - but there were no constant checks. The next day, Vicky brought a four-page suicide note Matthew had written in to his assessment. Vicky claims she and her husband were initially denied access to the meeting but were eventually allowed to be present after insisting they should be there. The family told mental health services they couldnapost look after Matthew on their own and he needed professional help, but claim they were asked aposwhere is this place you think we can keep him safe apos Matthewaposs parents suggested the psychiatric unit at Clatterbridge Hospital, but said they were told once again he was not mentally ill and had to take him home. Mental health services agreed to contact the home team for Matthew to receive visits. Vicky claims when the home team visited they promised they could give medication and section Matthewneeded. A -hour helpline was  also provided and the family started to feel they were being taken seriously. However, she claims the home team only visited three times before Matthew was discharged without telling his parents - with his third appointment allegedly lasting five minutes. Vicky also claims Matthew was not given any medication, a diagnosis or the chance to see a psychiatrist, but was given five sessions of cognitive behavioural therapy . It was recommended that Matthew visit the gym and consider ing to university. She said: I would take him to the gym and outside because I was petried he was going to leave and go somewhere. We would talk a lot about his illness together, he said he had constant pain in his head and had no zest for le. At the end of February , Vicky managed to get Matthew to see the familyaposs GP, as she believed her son was planning another suicide attempt. Their doctor urgently requested for Matthew to see a psychiatrist, writing in a letter aposI can no longer guarantee his safety.apos Vicky claims the request was rejected, but Matthew had one final appointment at Clatterbridge for  minutes. The mum alleges she was once again told her son did not have a mental health illness because Matthew told them he wasnapost going to end his le. Itaposs awful to see police tape over your childaposs bedroom door After three suicide attempts in just a few months, Matthew took his own le on April ,  - his fourth known attempt. Vicky said: He killed himself on April ,  and itaposs awful to see police tape over your childaposs bedroom door. He died on his own in his bedroom - that breaks my heart.

title: mum who told ba crew
story: NewsMum who told BA crew you have a massive a*** must wear anti-booze braceletLondon mum-of-two Emma Langford, , drunkenly hurled abuse and pummelled cabin crew on the British Airways flight to Cape Town, South AfricaShareCommentsByJoe Morgan:,  JAN NewsEmma Langford outside court where she admitted attacking BA staff on a plane " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA single mum who went on a drunken rampage on a British Airways jumbo jet has admitted attacking cabin crew staff. Emma Langford, , has admitted attacking BA staff on the flight to Cape Town in South Africa, punching the manager and kicking another in the back of the legs while screaming: “You have a massive ar*e.” She faces jail and must wear an anti-booze bracelet after her case was adjourned so the court could seek evidence she is seeking treatment for her alcoholism. During the incident, the mum-of-two had pulled out trays of stowed plates and glasses, causing them to shatter on the floor and cutting another member of staff before pummeling cabin crew. She eventually had to be restrained with the help of an off-duty police officer on the flight before being carried off the plane when it touched down in Cape Town. Langford had previously pleaded guilty to charges of three assaults, criminal damage, being drunk on an aircraft, and behaving in a threatening manner towards cabin crew. She faces up to two years imprisonment. Isleworth Crown Court heard how Langford, as part of matters relating to the custody of her two young sons, is now accompanied by a woman who observes her  hours a day and lives in her Old Baising, Hampshire home to ensure she does not drink alcohol. The -year-old is also to wear a SCRAM bracelet, a device that is able to detect alcohol in the system every half an hour.  Both the prosecutor and defence sought to adjourn the matter for a pre-sentence report to be completed and for the court to receive a letter from her psychiatrist. Prosecutor Douglas Adams said: “Ms Langford was on a British Airways flight to Cape Town, South Africa, when she assaulted three members of the cabin crew, broke crockery and glassware, and behaved in a threatening way to several members of the cabin crew. “She was flying to South Africa to attend a rehabilitation centre to seek treatment for her addiction. “She has two recent convictions for drinking and driving.” Guy Wyatt, defending Langford, said: “It’s a mystery why no one prior to this hearing made a pre-sentence report.  “There are mental health dficulties and a serious history of alcohol abuse at play here. “It’s my application for a full pre-sentence report to be completed. I acknowledge the case law is severe. It makes it clear that it’s a rare thing for anything other than a custodial sentence. “An immediate custodial sentence is the starting point. “This lady had a plan to go to an alcohol rehabilitation centre. It’s not been a story of success, unfortunately. “In the next few days, she’s going to be fitted with a SCRAM bracelet. It may be in the interest of the criminal courts to order this be observed.  “The bracelet has a sensor that reads alcohol in the sweat and makes a report every  minutes. “It arose from family proceedings of custody of her two children. She has two young sons. “The court will be assisted to see the observations of this bracelet, consulting reports of her psychiatrist and evidence from her sober companion. “She lives at her home, and is with her  hours a day. “If anyone can come back from this, it’s this lady.”  At Langford’s previous hearing at Ealing Magistrates Court on December , her actions were deemed “so serious” that she must be sentenced at a crown court. Recorder Joseph Boothby said: “It seems to me that you have a background and history the court will want to know before I consider the extreme measure of sentencing you to prison.

story: NewsopinionPlaying board games with my children over Christmas taught me a valuable lessonHighly competitive Saira Khan says you can learn a lot from playing games with your familyShareCommentsBySaira Khan:,  JAN NewsopinionSaira Khan said she has learnt a lesson playing board games " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor some lessons in the real world, dust off your board games. I’ve taught my ­children so much over the Christmas holidays by thrashing them at Cluedo and Monopoly. But our game of choice is ­Articulate – a describing game against the timer where your team mates have to guess the word. I was worried my eight-year-old daughter would go to piecesthe words were tricky. But I also made it very clear there were going to be no special favours just because of age. I’m highly competitive and clearly take no prisoners. Not even my beloved children. And that’s what they need to see – where you can lose everything on Park Lane to a -year-old man . They get to learn we are living in a world of snakes and ladders and sometimes le is not fair and can be as random as the roll of a dice. Board games also let me see what my kids are made of. Amara was on a mission to beat her older brother Zac. She happily squared up to her dad too. It was -year-old Zac who got frustrated.  He was hard on himself when he could not describe a country in the game. He didn’t like having gaps in his knowledge. And as his mum, nor did I. So what came out of our family fun time was that he wants to learn his world map. I’m happy with that – no way is he going to end up like that Apprentice chap who runs a travel company but couldn’t find Croatia on a globe because he’d only ever used a flat map before! One of my fondest memories is playing draughts with my dad. He was brilliant and taught me how to play. I loved seeingI could even get close to beating him. I rarely did. I never felt anxious but I did feel competitive and wanted to give it my best shot. And he’d always explain where I’d gone wrong. It connected us far more than ­plugging in a PS. Draughts is a game of strategy, thinking ahead, not steaming ahead. It taught me to keep having a go at something I wasn’t good at. And, yes, it also taught me I didn’t like losing.

story: NewsTricia Goddards mystery boyfriend makes her feel sexy again after cancer battleEXCLUSIVE: The mum-of-two refers to him only as “hashtag Boo” and said she may even be open to a fourth wedding despite having a string of failed relationships behind herShareCommentsByJanine Yaqoob:,  JAN NewsTrisha Goddard is a -year-old chat show queen " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - Strictly Come DancingSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTrisha Goddard says her mystery boyfriend has made her feel sexy again after breast cancer. And the -year-old chat show queen says she may even be open to a fourth wedding, despite having felt ashamed at her string of failed relationships. But she is keeping her American love’s identity a secret, even though they have been dating for two years. Quirkily, the mum-of-two refers to him only as “hashtag Boo” – but revealed he is the first man to have taken her out for a meal or bought her a ring. Trisha is one of the  celebrities lacing their skates for ITV’s new series of Dancing on Ice, which starts tonight. And although she is the oldest of the group, she insists she will give the youngsters a run for their money. Trisha said: “I might be the oldest in the competition but I’m the fittest, apart from Perri Kiely. “I thought, ‘Oh my god, these kids are so much younger’. But when you’re young you smoke, you drink, you stay up late. It takes a toll.” Diagnosed with breast cancer in , she added: “Physically, I’m very strong. Fitness post-breast cancer got me through. “I know how important it is for my body and mind.” The telly host suffered depression in the s, even attempting to take her own le.  But she says running, weights and resistance bands help to keep the dark thoughts in check. “If I haven’t run for a few days I start feeling like I’m losing control. “Feeling the rain, wind and sun in my face is so special. It got me through my treatment.” And it has made her love her body again – and feel comfortable getting intimate with her new boyfriend. She explained: “I was very wary, having gone through breast cancer, about opening up to someone. I’m not ashamed of my body but you become aware of the changes. “I wear a pressure sleeve – it ain’t the sexiest thing. You go into a new relationship and think, ‘Oh no…’ But #Boo lost his first we from breast cancer.  “Here’s somebody where I don’t even have to finish the sentence. It’s more than the physical, it’s the mental side too. I couldnapost talk with my ex because he was so traumatised by it. “As a woman at the centre of a family you thinkyou appear weak the whole family will fall down. “#Boo completely got it. He makes me feel sexy. If I’m coming down the stairs he tells me how beautul I look. “He buys me gorgeous clothes and can’t wait to see me in them.” Trisha met her beau through a US friend where she now lives, in Connecticut. She said: “#Boo was going through a orce too. We didn’t expect to meet – we were sat at the same table. “We laughed all night, that was two years ago. This is the first time I’ve had a partner that earns more than me, it’s a novelty.  “And I rather like it. He’ll wine and dine me. Can you believe, I had to wait until I was  to be bought a meal  “He bought me a Tfany ring, it’s the first ring a man has ever bought me.” The cancer battle put a huge pressure on her -year marriage to third husband Peter Gianfrancesco, and relationships with daughters Billie Dee, , and Madi, , her children from her second marriage to Mark Grieve. Her first marriage was in  to Australian politician Robert Nestdale, who she later learned was gay. PR manager Billie talked last year about her -year battle with drink and drugs, saying her mum’s absence in her childhood was partly to blame. Trisha admits the family have had their problems, but insists they are as strong as ever after working through it.  She said: “We’re the three musketeers. When one falls, the others help them up. “Last year was a family transition. One of us will go through s**t and will create s**t for the other person.” And she admitted: “I put them through a lot of s**t. We don’t do it to be nasty, we do it because we’re in pain. “Billie was hurt, she was struggling to find a way to deal with it. She’s done an amazing job to come through it. “I’m proud of the young women they’ve grown to be.” Trisha was the first black woman to front a British chat show, rising to fame in  with ITV’s Trisha.  The show switched to Channel  in . She moved to the US when it was axed in . Excited and nervous to be back on prime time UK TV, she admits that what worries her most is remembering the routines – despite the coaching from judges Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean. She said: “I’ve got chemo brain, which really affects my memory, and menopause on top of that. “Skating really helps. I used to get frustrated. “This is really helping as the brain responds to exercise. “If I can remember my whole dance routine you’ll see me get very emotional.  “I can still remember guests from years ago, but short-term memory isn’t great. “I hated the fact I lost my memory, I got angry as it was my living for so long.” She has bonded well with her fellow celebs – but has already developed a reputation for straight-talking backstage. She said: “I like my own space. When they all start talking about how scared they are, I remove myself from the group, get my skipping rope out and skip. “They think I’m mad. If they talk about fear or how much pain they’re in, then I don’t want to hear it. “I didn’t join support groups when I had my cancer treatment. I didn’t want to sit around playing ‘My chemo side effects are worse than yours’. I want to be out in the fresh air, or skipping.”  So what’s next for Trisha after Dancing on Ice  Marriage number four  “I could get married again. A part of me allowed other people to make me feel ashamed about the amount of times I was married.

story: NewsIran identies  targets for retaliatory strikes after US execute General SoleimaniAn Iranian official says the country will target key US allies and warns Israel is within reach amid its leaderships vow of revenge after the US-ordered execution of top General Qassem SoleimaniShareCommentsByTalia ShadwellReuters:,  JAN NewsA shrine to assassinated top Iranian military general Qasem Soleimani in Moscow, Russia " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIran has identied  targets around the Middle East as punishment for the US executing general Qassem Soleimani, a top Iranian official claims.The countryaposs leadership has vowed revenge after the US-ordered execution of the powerful Iranian general. Iran has pledged to target Americans wherever they are within reach in retaliation for the killing, Tasnim news agency has today quoted a senior Revolutionary Guards commander as saying.General Gholamali Abuhamzeh, the commander of the Guards in the southern province of Kerman, raised the prospect of possible attacks on ships in the Gulf - also warning Tel Aviv in Israel, is within reach.The threats come amid high tensions worldwide and concentrating in the GUl, with rockets falling near a US Embassy in the Iraqi capital of Baghdad earlier today. At least five people were injured as rockets fell in the Iraqi cityaposs Green Zone, which houses government buildings and foreign missions.The incident comes a day after US President Donald Trump ordered the drone execution of Soleimani at Baghdad Airport, sparking fears echoed around social media of the threat of a World War III.Iranaposs countryaposs supreme leader Ali Khamenei stoked global fears of war as he vowed revenge over his generalaposs death, adding: I and the government and the nation of Iran strongly condemn this American crime. Iran reserved the right to take revenge against the US for the death of Soleimani, Mr Abuhamzeh added in comments made late on Friday and reported on by Tasnim today. The Strait of Hormuz is a vital point for the West and a large number of American destroyers and warships cross there ... vital American targets in the region have been identied by Iran since long time ago ... some  US targets in the region as well as Tel Aviv are within our reach, he said.  An expert on the region speculated the targets could include key ally states and assets around the Middle East. Eric Edelman, a former ambassador to Turkey during George W. Bushaposs presidency said Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and Bahrain are likely targets for Iranaposs wrath. Iran had already attacked the computer networks of oil and gas targets run by Saudi and Qatar interests.Mr Edelman said the plots could also reach far beyond the Gulf region, telling Time today: “They will look for ways to hit us where we don’t expect it,” he says.“But they will be patient. When their nose is bloodied, they tend to take a step back and reassess, before making the next move.”  Another expert, Douglas Silliman, also told the magazineaposs website that American targets and allies in the region faced danger. He said strikes may not necessarily come against American targets, as Iran had a history of targeting Saudi oil facilities and shipping. He warned that people with links to American personnel in the region could also come into Iranaposs crosshairs.

title: sas sent iraq evacuate brits
story: NewsSAS sent to Iraq to evacuate Brits from terror hotspot as Iran tensions soarEXCLUSIVE: The SAS have been forced to move into Iraq to helpBritish people after a US air strike killed a high-ranking Iranian generalShareCommentsBySean RaymentAlan Selby:,  JAN NewsThe SAS are heading out to the Middle East as tensions soar following the US assassination of Iran’s top military commander" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe SAS are heading out to the Middle East tonight for a ­possible rescue mission as ­tensions soared after the US killed Iran’s top military man. Britain’s most elite forces have been mobilised in the wake of President Trump’s ­ordering the assassination of General Qassem Soleimani, . He died in a Reaper drone missile strike near Baghdad airport in ­neighbouring Iraq on Friday. It is understood around  members of the Special Air Service and the Navy’s Special Boat Service along with the Special Forces Support Group will be sent to Iraq to help any possible ­evacuation of Britons in the region. There are at least , military and UK government civilian personnel in Iraq as part of Operation Shader which is the UK mission to help train Iraqi and Kurdish forces defeat Islamic State. Boris Johnson is expected toto London from ­holiday in time for ministerial meetings in No on Monday amid fears of all-out war breaking out in the Gulf.It is understood defence chiefs have ordered British troops in Iraq – numbering around  – to be on high alert following the assassination. Senior commanders are concerned that British nationals could be targeted by Iranian-backed Shia militia groups based inside Iraq. Soleimani was the head of Iran’s elite Quds Force and mastermind of Iran’s Middle East operations. He has been blamed for the deaths and maiming of thousands of British and American troops in operations across the Middle East over decades. One senior UK defence source said: “Soleimani was an enemy combatant in  a war zone who was deploying to oversee and orchestrate Iranian ­operations in a foreign country which would have resulted in the deaths of US soldiers, ­civilians and potentially British personnel as well.  “He knew the risks and took his chances as all troops do and he paid the price.  “Soleimani had been a marked man for quite a while. He had the blood of many British soldiers on his hands. “The attack was all about sending a message to the Iranian leadership and that is that the US can get at you at any time and in any place.” Last night several rockets landed near the US embassy in Baghdad, injuring five people. Three more rockets were reportedly fired at Balad Airbase housing American troops north of Baghdad. In another development Defence Secretary Ben Wallace announced British warships would resume ­operations in the Strait of Hormuz. HMS Montrose and HMS Defender are already in the Gulf and will act as escorts to British tankers to prevent them being seized by Iran’s navy. Mr Wallace said: “The Government will take all necessary steps to protect our ships and citizens at this time.” At least  targets in the US and Israel have been identied by Iran for retaliatory strikes after the country’s president vowed to exact revenge for the killing of General Soleimani. Targets include ships in the Persian Gulf, the Strait of Hormuz and Tel Aviv. The US State Department said: “General Soleimani was actively developing plans to ­attack American diplomats and service members in Iraq and throughout the region.”  Thousands of mourners chanted “Death to America” yesterday as they marched in Soleimani’s funeral procession in Baghdad as US and UK flags were publicly burned. It is feared that all-out war could break out in the regionIran calls on its allies Russia and China to help as tensions rise. The Foreign Office yesterday strengthened its warnings over travel to the Middle East. British nationals were advised not to travel to Iraq or Iran. The Foreign Office warned that anyone in Iraq outside the Kurdistan region should consider leaving by ­commercial means because the ­uncertain security situation could ­deteriorate quickly. Alerts regarding other Middle East nations were also being increased, with warnings that Britons should remain vigilant in Afghanistan, Israel, Lebanon and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab , who will visit the US next week to meet with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in a previously planned visit, said: “The first job of any Government is to keep British people safe.” An American official denied the nation was behind a second air strike on two vehicles north of Baghdad. Iraq’s state TV reported that the attack killed six people in a medical convoy.US president Donald Trump said his order to kill Soleimani was “to stop a war, not to start one”.Back in  Soleimani was involved in backing pro-Iranian militia groups in southern Iraq. These factions targeted British troops with bombs and rockets, killing and maiming a signicant number. In response the SAS set up a special operation to wipe out the Iranian-backed cells. But a mission to kill Soleimani was reportedly blocked by David Miliband, then Foreign Secretary. A British military source said: “The Foreign Secretary said that he wanted to talk to the Iranians, not kill them. “We had Soleimani in our ­crosshairs, but we had to call the operation off because of sensitivities in London about conducting this type of operation.” There has been criticism of the US for not giving advanced notice of the attack to the UK. Former Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said the failure to noty was regrettable because allies should ensure there are no surprises in the relationship.Mr Hunt said: “This is a very, very risky situation, and I think the job that we have to do as one of the US’s closest allies is to use our influence.” Friday’s attack also killed four Iranian Islamic Revolutionary Guards and five of Iraq’s pro-Iran paramilitaries.

title: dundee united 1 1 dundee dorrans first goal earns dee derby point
story: Graham Dorrans# first goal for Dundee earned his side a point as they came from behind at Tannadice to end Dundee United#s derby dominance.Nicky Clark had given league leaders United an early advantage but Dorrans rled home the equaliser in the second period to end the Terrors# nine-game winning streak and perfect derby record this season.Dundee were unchanged from their win over Partick last weekend while Louis Appere replaced the injured Sam Stanton for United.And it was the Tangerines who got off to a dream start in front of a , near-sell-out, scoring with the first attack and shot of the game after just five minutes.Appere released Jamie Robson on the overlap down the left and the full-back#s delivery was flicked home by Clark for his seventh goal of the season.Action threatened to boil over on  minutes as Robson and Dundee#s Paul McGowan exchanged handbags in the corner but referee Alan Muir kept his cards in his pocket.And it was McGowan who had the Dark Blues# first real chance of the game on  minutes.The -year-old picked up on a Jordan Marshall cut back, twisted and turned in the box to make some space but saw his shot deflected behind for a corner.On  minutes McGowan was again denied by Siegrist inside the box as he collected a lovely reverse pass from -year-old Fin Robertson but couldn#t find a way past the big Swiss.Terrors talisman Lawrence Shankland had his first clear-cut chance of the game  minutes before half-time but couldn#t head home from six yards out after Robson#s delivery.Calum Butcher escaped a booking on two counts as he went in heavy on Danny Johnson and McGowan as tempers began to flare as the game approached half-time.Dee keeper Jack Hamilton did well to deny Ian Harkes from close range to keep the score down at the interval.Much like the opening period, there was an early goal to start the second half # and it was Dundee who got it.Five minutes after the action restarted Dorrans got on the end of Liam Smith#s clearance to rle home a left-footed volley for his first goal for the club.With the match level, the Dark Blues almost took the lead moments later as Johnson was inches away from getting on the end of a Sean Mackie cross.On  minutes, Shankland went close as he nodded Paul McMullan#s cross just wide of Hamilton#s left-hand post as both teams pushed for a winner.However, both sides had to settle for a point apiece as they go into the new year United sitting top and Dundee in play-off contention.Dundee United XI : SiegristL Smith, Watson, Reynolds , Robson Butcher, Harkes, McMullan, Clark , Appere Shankland.Subs not used: Deniz , Connolly, C Smith, Chalmers, King and Mochrie.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, McGhee, Meekings , Marshall McGowan, Robertson, Dorrans, Mackie Hemmings, Johnson .Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Todd, Byrne, Moore and Mulligan.Ref: Alan Muir.Att: , .

title: hydrogen buses social media contact lenses and climate change dundees predictions for the next decade
story: With the beginning of a new decade, many people are thinking about what the future might hold for them.Top scientists and academics predict a world of houses built by D printers and  internet connected devices per person.It is also predicted that over % of all cars purchased will be self-driving, and that flying cars will finally be on the streets and in the air.Many Dundonians share this vision, with technology, renewable energy and climate change all being major parts of the predictions made by the city#s residents.Cameron Price, , an employee at Hawkin#s Bazar, said: #There will be even more reliance on handheld technology like their phones.#I#m sure many folk have seen the TV show Blackmirror where people are wearing their contact lenses to identy each other.#I also think that the use of Facebook will be a lot more prevalent in applying for a job. You#ll apply with a Facebook account instead of a CV.#Many in the city also expressed great concern over climate change and its part in the city#s future.Graham Farquhar, a -year-old office worker from Perth, said: #I think that major changes will have to take place in the climate control situation.#I#ve got a granddaughter who#s five and it#s an important time for the world and her growing up in the next  years.#Architect, Rob Pederson, , also believes that climate change will be a huge part of the next decade. He said: #My predictions for  would be an increase in the level of electric vehicles across Scotland with a wider infrastructure being applied.#Also, on a much more exciting note there will be an opportunity to introduce hydrogen buses. #We#re going to take  buses and put them on the roads in Dundee and have zero emissions and the hope is that we#ll have jobs coming out of it.#Lauren Morsley, , an employee at Lush, said: #A lot more people are conscious about eating more plant based foods, cutting down on the amount of meat and animal products they consume.#With soaps that#s the easiest part to do because you can get the exact same product but without all the animal byproducts in it. I definitely see it as an ongoing trend.#Environmental sustainability student, Sarah Clark, , predicts that environmental issues will define the coming years.She said: #I think in the next  years we will have a greater pressure on resources and a wider ide between the % and the rest.#I think that because Dundee already has some definite problems in terms of a fair economy and a lot of people are in debt and poverty. That resource pressure could have a very big effect on people in Dundee who are already struggling.#However, some are more optimistic about the city#s future.Sara White, ,  an employee at Tartan House of Scotland, said: #I think that between the cruise ships coming in for the VA and restaurants opening up and more tourist type shops like this one, we will hopefully see an increase in people coming into the city centre and spending their money.#

title: osman sows future at dundee united in doubt
story: Osman Sow’s Dundee United future is up in the air after he ed to the club from Kilmarnock.The Swedish hitman joined United on an -month contract last January before signing a six-month loan deal at top-flight Killie in the summer.That agreement was due to end in the middle of the month, with Sow having only made nine appearances without scoring for the Rugby Park club.However, it was cut short early by the Ayrshire outfit on Monday night as Alex Dyer took over the reins after a spell as caretaker manager.Dyer was previously No  under now-Scotland boss Steve Clarke and takes over after performing the same role for previous incumbent Angelo Alessio.With Sow’s deal at United up at the end of the season it remains to be seen what happens with the big striker in the meantime.He is unlikely to be offered a new contract with the Terrors pushing for the Premiership and finds himself behind Lawrence Shankland, Nicky Clark and Louis Appere in the pecking order.An early release or seeing out his contract looks the most likely outcome for the -year-old former Hearts forward.“Osman’s contract with Kilmarnock was up in the middle of January,” United boss Robbie Neilson said.“With the change of manager it was a bit up in the air at but it was up to them what they wanted to do.”Elsewhere, Troy Brown will exit Tannadice at the end of the week when his contract expires, with Declan Glass set toto the club from his loan at Cove Rangers.Logan Chalmers is expected to go the other way, out to Arbroath on loan, with Robbie currently looking at trialists as he aims to add one or two more to his squad in the winter window.“We would like to bring in one or two in January and maybe move one or two on as well.“They’ve got to be one’s that impact the first team and they have to be good characters.“I’ve got a couple in on trial, some younger ones as well and we’re always looking. That’s the thing at this time of year,you can get them in for a week then great but nothing’s nailed down.“The January market is always a strange one because you can do all the planning you want then someone you don’t expect comes up so you have to move quickly.”

title: things starting to click for dee says skip josh
story: Josh Meekings says things are starting to click for Dundee as they head into the new year but knows better than most how tough a task they face this weekend.The Dens Park skipper reckons the second-half performance at Tannadice last Friday night showed the Dark Blues have learned lessons from the first half of the campaign.And he plans, along with his team-mates, to continue to put those lessons into practice against Inverness at Dens on Saturday.The central defender, who lted the Scottish Cup as Caley Thistle captain in , said: “Saturday is another tough one against Inverness at home.“We know what Inverness are like. They have been very good this season, picking up points and had been on a little run up until last Saturday.“I keep repeating myself to everybody but it is only about us and what we do because we can’t affect anybody ’s results, we need to keep plugging away ourselves like we have been doing.“Last Friday was a bit more positive compared with the previous two derbies – I think we learned from those games.“As a group we are all learning together and getting better. I think that is starting to show on the pitch.“Looking back over the past few weeks, at the time you want three points at Arbroath but, in hindsight, it was a decent point in hard conditions.“They are no mugs and showed that at the weekend again.“We went into Dunfermline and Partick and picked up two positive results but we are taking it a game at a time, maintaining our focus and working hard.“That’s all we can do, trust the management and then trust what we can do on the pitch.“We had so many bodies coming in during the summer, a massive turnover and that always takes a little while.“The manager has changed things, formations, tactics, and I do feel we are starting to click a bit better.“It’s only positive right now for us and we need to keep our head down. We can only do our job and not bother about other teams in the league.”Skipper Meekings and his team-mates took a lot out of the - draw at leaders Dundee United, particularly after going behind so early.“We showed a lot of character and dug in last Friday,” he added.“We’d been behind before in derbies and obviously suffered after that but this time we showed a bit of character and got back into it in the second half.“I think the last  minutes we gave it our all but couldn’t quite get that second goal.“It’s a good point on the road after a good period where we have picked up some points.“We had a sticky period and we’ve got out of it.“It was dficult at Tannadice the previous time so it is a bit more positive.”The -year-old, however, admits he feared the Dark Blues could have been in for another long night at Tannadice after Nicky Clark nipped in front of him to score after five minutes.A few choice words at half-time, though, brought out much better from Dundee in the second period.“When you are a centre-half and an early goal goes in against you, you think ‘we’ve got it all to do now’.“The boys dug deep, we all got stuck in – there was a bit said at half-time between the players and we needed that.“Moving forward, we need that drive and energy because it is a long season still – we are only halfway done and there is plenty to play for.”Meekings was also pleased to be able to give the club’s fans a cheerier festive period after a pretty gloomy .He added: “Hopefully, we gave our fans a decent Christmas and they could enjoy the New Year a bit more.“We would have loved to have given them three points but I think we showed passion and did everything we could last Friday.“We couldn’t quite get that second goal but it is a positive result.“If you show energy and passion like that, the fans will respond.“We wanted the three points but the derby was a positive point and the fans kept backing us.“We’ll keep fighting for them.”

story: More than  admissions have been made for adults and children seeking treatment at a north-east eating disorder clinic in the last five years, new figures have shown.The figures released under freedom of information show  adults have been treated at the Eden Unit at Royal Cornhill Hospital in Aberdeen since .In -, a total of  admissions were made to the unit, eventually reducing to  in -.However, this rose again in the last year, when  admissions were recorded for patients seeking treatment.North-east MSP Tom Mason said: “Both adults and youngsters feel pressure to look a certain way and this can often be escalated by what they see on TV, for example.“The situation is alarming but I’m glad people are realising they may be suffering from an eating disorder and are therefore being seen to.”The figures also show  patients were discharged from hospital in -, down from a five-year high of  in -.An NHS Grampian spokesman said: “The figures show a downward trend in admissions since -. This comes despite the population of the region increasing during the same period.“The Eden Unit at Royal Cornhill Hospital takes referrals from NHS Grampian, NHS Highland, NHS Tayside, NHS Orkney, NHS Shetland, NHS Western Isles as well as occasional out-of-area referrals.“In most cases, patient admissions are a proactive way to prevent their condition from escalating in severity. title: we should do all we can to get var says mcinnes
story: Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes accepts the controversial VAR isn’t perfect but still reckons Scottish football should introduce it.As early as April this year the SFA is planning to ask member clubs to vote on the potential introduction of the system.VAR has been criticised in England for being too forensic, with decisions on offside coming down to mere millimetres.Rangers this week called for Scotland to introduce VAR following what the Ibrox club viewed as contentious decisions in recent games.If given the go-ahead in Scotland, VAR would cost a reported £ million per year to implement.McInnes insists the controversial Video Assisted Referee is worth the expense –utilised correctly.He said: “We should be doing all we can to get VAR.“It is not perfect by a long way and is still causing problems. Referees need to use it better in England by looking at the monitor more and taking a bit more time to consider the situation and get the right decision.“For major decisions, such as sendings-off and goals, I still think the stats show it works. They get about % of decisions right, which is a lot more than we get now in these situations.”SFA chief executive Ian Maxwell recently commissioned a study into the costs and benefits of bringing the controversial system to the Scottish game.Chairmen of member Scottish clubs will be askedthey will be willing to follow the footsteps of England, where VAR was introduced at the start of the current season.Scotland’s leading referees have reportedly backed the introduction of VAR, which has been used in major tournaments such as the  World Cup and  Women’s World Cup.Maxwell recently said: “In the early part of  we need to be goingand saying, ‘there’s the cost, guys, do you want to do it or not ’”In the aftermath of the recent - win at Celtic, Rangers managing director Stewart Robertson, in a club statement, urged Scottish football chiefs to get on board with VAR to help assist referees with dficult decisions.However, the system has been heavily criticised south of the border for being used wrongly to reverse marginal errors.Five goals in the Premier League were ruled out last weekend for marginal offsides, leading some managers and players to slate VAR.In November Liverpool striker Roberto Firmino was denied a goal against Aston Villa after the VAR team declared a goal-scoring part of his body was offside – in this case his armpit.McInnes still reckons VAR,used correctly, can reduce errors. He said: “VAR minimises the mistakes and frustrations sometimes with decisions.“It is something we should be going all out to get into our game.”It is expected the projected £m annual cost will have to be paid by the clubs.That will likely come from the league distribution prize pot, which is the money left over when all other costs are taken off, or the SFA prize pot distributed to clubs.There is also the possibility the new £m deal with Sky Sports for the Premiership television rights could fund VAR.The Sky Sports deal begins at the start of the - campaign and runs for five years, with the broadcaster screening up to  games per season.A six-year Scottish Cup deal with BBC Scotland and Premier Sports worth £m was also recently confirmed by the SFA.Ultimately whether Scotland will introduce VAR will come down to the finances and whether lower-league clubs will be willing to sacrice some of their income for something only implemented in the top flight.A recent incident where VAR would have been pertinent was the controversial red card shown to Sam Cosgrove in the - defeat to Celtic at Parkhead.Cosgrove was shown a straight red by referee Euan Anderson for a challenge on Kristoffer Ajer.The Aberdeen striker clearly won the ball when running in at speed and footage confirmed that.Aberdeen appealed the dismissal and subsequent two-game ban.However, the appeal was rejected by a fast-track disciplinary  and Cosgrove’s suspension stood for the games against Livingston and Hearts.In the immediate aftermath of the Celtic defeat, McInnes admitted VAR could have helped Cosgrove’s cause.He said: “VAR could have helped out, but you still need the referee to make the right decision.”McInnes is for VAR but it will take the majority of the other  clubs to agree for the controversial system to be introduced.

title: meet rg mowat owner of the fulmar
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt the end of November we asked readers for help to unravel the mystery of a yacht log book which was posted to the paper with no clues as to its origin.And, not for the first time, Argyllshire Advertiser readers have come up trumps and we now know a little more about the boat#s owner, named only as RG Mowat in the log book.The  log book gives an account of the voyages of the -foot gaff cutter #Fulmar# and the adventures of her colourful crew. Its dog-eared pages contain neatly-typed records, precise drawings and fascinating photographs.The log#s mystery is deepened by the fact no names are given other than the nicknames #Tanky#, #Bosun#, #Skipper# and #Pilot#. The only crew member named is pet dachshund #Major#.The log does record the Fulmar#s home port was Tighnabruaich and the owner was RG Mowat, but few details on Mr Mowat could be found.Lord Weir of Lochhead, Achahoish, contacted the newspaper to pass on information on Commander Ralph G Mowat.During the Second World War, Commander Mowat was a Royal Navy Captain, latterly in command of a cruiser. At the end of the war, he and his ship entered Copenhagen, where he took the surrender of the German troops.Clive Brown from Ardfern added some post-war detail. He revealed: #Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , was a distinguished member of Clyde Cruising Clubbest known as being, for  years, the honorary editor of the CCC Sailing Directions . These were # and indeed remain # a #must have# for everyone who navigates their way among the many lochs and islands of Scotland#s west coast. They were colloquially known as the #Blue Book# and published at that time as a hardback. He also served as CCC Rear Commodore -.#Mr Brown also provided an extract from the book #Clyde Cruising Club, The First One Hundred Years -# which states Ralph Mowat received an RYA Award for services to yachting in  but refused to accept honorary membership of the club. In recompense, his widow Mary was elected an honorary member in , after his death.Tighnabruaich man Alan Wilson contacted Clyde sailing legend Ian Nicolson, who was fairly sure he recalled racing against the #Fulmar# in the s.Mr Nicolson said:#Old Man Mowat, as I remember him, was a typical ex Royal Navy officer. He treated me as a young upstart, which I was, but we got on well because I wrote a bit for Clyde Cruising Club publications. He lived in Clarkston on the edge of Glasgow.#Clyde Cruising Club itself cannot help with information on the Fulmar. Club secretary Jenner Rollands contacted the Advertiser and confirmed CCC sadly lost all its records when the Carrick, moored on the River Clyde, sank in . At the time, the club#s office was aboard her.Closer to home, Ardrishaig man Billy Paterson called into the Advertiser offices to say his father, Ardrishaig Primary School headmaster Gilbert Paterson, had crewed the yacht Fulmar.Mr Paterson still has mementoes from his father#s trips in the form of gts from Commander Mowat, including a paperweight from , a copper and brass barrel ashtray dated  and a brass model yacht with #Fulmar # engraved on it.Thanks to everyone who contacted the Advertiser with their memories.We now know a little more about Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , owner of the Fulmar.Details about the crew of #Tanky#, #Bosun# and #Pilot# remain, however, sketchy, soanyone out there knows any more#
